article.headline: Stephens plays 2 minutes in second half
article.linkText: Stephens sits with fouls, but helps Texas win
article.story:
DALLAS (AP) -- Texas' Stacy Stephens made the most of her two
second-half minutes.

After dominating Baylor's short-handed interior defense in the
first half for 14 points and four rebounds, Stephens spent most of
the second half on the bench with foul trouble.

But she came back to hit one more basket, a short fadeaway with
35 seconds left, sealing No. 2 Texas' 63-59 victory over No. 14
Baylor on Thursday night and putting the Longhorns in the Big 12
conference title game for the second straight year.

"Going out was really tough," said Stephens, who finished with
16 points and seven rebounds. "I made sure I stayed focused. I
knew we needed a big shot, and thankfully it went in."

The Longhorns (28-3) face No. 19 Oklahoma in the championship
game on Saturday after the Sooners defeated eighth-ranked Kansas
State 78-66.

Stephens pounded Baylor (24-8), posting up for most of her 14
first-half points before getting into foul trouble early in the
second half. She took just two shots after the break, but the last
one, a twisting shot in the paint, put Texas up 61-57.

"It's always difficult when you lose Stacy, because she's our
only senior and she's our go-to player in those situations," Texas
coach Jody Conradt said.

"Stacy is just a big body in there; you just don't move her,"
Baylor coach Kim Mulkey-Robertson.

Texas also got 19 points from Nina Norman, who was 8-of-12 from
the field and made two free throws with five seconds left.

"Nina has been really good throughout this tournament in terms
of making shots," Conradt said. "Nina plays with confidence. If
she doesn't play the way she played, we probably don't win those
two games."

Baylor closed to 59-57 on Sophia Young's free throw with 57
seconds left. Young, picking up much of the scoring slack because
Baylor was without injured center Steffanie Blackmon, had 30
points, nine rebounds and five steals.

Blackmon, who averages 15.6 points and 6.9 rebounds, twisted her
left knee in a quarterfinals victory Wednesday over No. 10 Texas
Tech.

Young scored 20 of Baylor's 24 points after halftime, and her
two free throws with 8:38 left put Baylor ahead 53-48. But then the
Lady Bears, who shot 33 percent after halftime, went without a
score for the next seven minutes. Young ended the skid with a short
jumper.

"I didn't think we took care of the ball like we should. I just
think Texas turned up the pressure and we folded," she said.

Texas led 37-35 at halftime on Norman's 3-pointer with 9 seconds
left. The Longhorns twice built five-point leads in the first half
and appeared to be breaking away. But Baylor came back both times.

Texas went up 20-15, but Jessika Stratton's short jumper capped
a 10-2 run that put Baylor in front 25-22. Texas went up 34-29 on
back-to-back 3-pointers by Heather Schreiber and Jamie Carey's
short runner in the lane.

But Young's slashing layup with 36 seconds left before halftime
put the Lady Bears back up 35-34.

Dionne Brown was the only other Baylor player in double figures,
with all 12 of her points coming in the first half. But she missed
all three shots in the second half.

Texas, the regular-season co-champion with Kansas State, was the
top seed in the tournament for the second straight year. The
Longhorns won the tournament last season and advanced to the Final
Four of the NCAA tournament, where they lost to eventual champion
Connecticut.

Texas has won 14 of 15 games since losing to Baylor in January,
and has won 45 of 49 overall.
